standard_metadata.standard_description: Make a line plot to display a data set of measurements in fractions of a unit (1/2, 1/4, 1/8). Solve problems involving addition and subtraction of fractions by using information presented in line plots.
standard_metadata.standard_title: Graph data on line plots (through 1/8 of a unit)

question.content: For $4$ days, you record the number of hours you sleep each night.  You round each time to the nearest $\dfrac{1}{4}$ of an hour.  Day | Sleep time (hours) :-: | :-: Day $1$ | $7\dfrac{1}{4}$ Day $2$ | $7\dfrac{3}{4}$ Day $3$ | $7\dfrac{3}{4}$ Day $4$ | $8\dfrac{1}{2}$  **Create a line plot that shows all of the measurements on the number line below.**    *Click above tick marks to add dots; click on tick marks to remove dots.*

hints.content: The number line has $4$ equal parts per whole, so each interval has a length of $\dfrac{1}{4}$.   Let's number the rest of the number line.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line that has, moving left to right, labeled tick marks at seven, seven and one-fourth, seven and one-half, seven and three-fourths, eight, eight and one-fourth, eight and one-half, eight and three-fourths, and nine. The tick marks at 7, 8, and 9 are emphasized.

hints.content: There are repeats in the data. Let's summarize the information into a frequency table.  Sleep time (hours) | Frequency :-: | :-: $7\dfrac{1}{4}$ | $1$ $7\dfrac{3}{4}$ | $2$ $8\dfrac{1}{2}$ | $1$  The frequency tells us how many dots to put above each number on the line plot.  For example, we need $2$ dots above the value $7\dfrac{3}{4}$ hours.  Now we can plot each sleep time and its frequency.
The correctly graphed measurements are:    [[☃ plotter 2]]

question.content: The lengths of $5$ adult killer whales are shown in the table below.  The lengths are rounded to the nearest $\dfrac{1}{8}$ of a yard.  Whale | Length (yards) :-: | :-: Maestro | $7\dfrac{3}{4}$ Willy | $8\dfrac{7}{8}$ Namu | $8\dfrac{1}{4}$ Tom | $7\dfrac{5}{8}$ Midge | $7\dfrac{3}{4}$  **Create a line plot that shows all of the measurements on the number line below.**   *Click above tick marks to add dots; click on tick marks to remove dots.*

hints.content: The number line has $8$ equal parts per whole, so each interval has a length of $\dfrac{1}{8}$.   Let's number the rest of the number line.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line that has, moving left to right, labeled tick marks at seven and one-half, seven and five-eighths, seven and three-fourths, seven and seven-eighths, eight, eight and one-eighth, eight and one-fourth, eight and three-eighths, eight and one-half, eight and five-eighths, eight and three-fourths, eight and seven eighths, and nine. The tick marks at 8 and 9 are emphasized.

hints.content: There are repeats in the data. Let's summarize the information into a frequency table.  Length (yards) | Frequency :-: | :-: $7\dfrac{3}{4}$ | $2$ $8\dfrac{7}{8}$ | $1$ $8\dfrac{1}{4}$ | $1$ $7\dfrac{5}{8}$ | $1$  The frequency tells us how many dots to put above each number on the line plot.  For example, we need $2$ dots above the value $7\dfrac{3}{4}$ yards.  Now we can plot each length and its frequency.
The correctly graphed measurements are:    [[☃ plotter 1]]

question.content: Gino records how much milk his family drinks each week in February.    Week | Milk (gal) :-: | :-: $1$ | $3\dfrac{3}{4}$ $2$ | $2\dfrac{1}{4}$ $3$ | $3\dfrac{3}{4}$ $4$ | $1\dfrac{1}{2}$  **Create a line plot that shows all of the measurements on the number line below.**    *Click above tick marks to add dots; click on tick marks to remove dots.*

hints.content: The number line has $4$ equal parts per whole, so each interval has a length of $\dfrac{1}{4}$.   Let's number the rest of the number line.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line that has, moving left to right, labeled tick marks at one, one and one-fourth, one and one-half, one and three-fourths, two, two and one-fourth, two and one-half, two and three-fourths, three, three and one-fourth, three and one-half, three and three-fourths, four. The tick marks at 1, 2, 3, and 4 are emphasized.

hints.content: There are repeats in the data. Let's summarize the information into a frequency table.  Milk (gal) | Frequency :-: | :-: $3\dfrac{3}{4}$ | $2$ $2\dfrac{1}{4}$ | $1$ $1\dfrac{1}{2}$ | $1$  The frequency tells us how many dots to put above each number on the line plot.  For example, we need $2$ dots above the value $3\dfrac{3}{4}$ gallons.  Now we can plot each volume and its frequency.
The correctly graphed measurements are:    [[☃ plotter 1]]

question.content: The owner of a produce stand is selling bunches of grapes, priced by the pound.  The table below shows the weights of several bunches of grapes rounded to the nearest $\dfrac{1}{8}$ of a pound.  Bunch | Weight (lb) :-: | :-: Bunch $1$ | $\dfrac{5}{8}$ Bunch $2$ | $1\dfrac{7}{8}$ Bunch $3$ | $1\dfrac{5}{8}$ Bunch $4$ | $\dfrac{6}{8}$ Bunch $5$ | $\dfrac{6}{8}$  **Create a line plot that shows all of the measurements on the number line below.**    *Click above tick marks to add dots; click on tick marks to remove dots.*

hints.content: The number line has $8$ equal parts per whole, so each interval has a length of $\dfrac{1}{8}$.   Let's number the rest of the number line.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line that has, moving left to right, labeled tick marks at zero, one-eighth, one-fourth, three-eighths, one-half, five-eighths, three-fourths, seven-eighths, one, one and one-eighth, one and one-fourth, one and three-eighths, one and  one-half, one and five-eighths, one and three-fourths, one and seven-eighths, and two.  The tick marks at 0, 1, and 2 are emphasized.

hints.content: There are repeats in the data. Let's summarize the information into a frequency table.  Weight (lb) | Frequency :-: | :-: $\dfrac{5}{8}$ | $1$ $1\dfrac{7}{8}$ | $1$ $1\dfrac{5}{8}$| $1$ $\dfrac{6}{8}$ | $2$  The frequency tells us how many dots to put above each number on the line plot.  For example, we need $2$ dots above the value $\dfrac{6}{8}$ pounds.  Now we can plot each weight and its frequency.
The correctly graphed measurements are:    [[☃ plotter 1]]

question.content: The amount of rain that fell in Tokyo, Japan for $3$ consecutive days is shown in the table below.  The measurements are rounded to the nearest $\dfrac{1}{8}$ of an inch.  Day | Rainfall (in) :-: | :-: Day $1$ | $1\dfrac{1}{8}$ Day $2$ | $1\dfrac{3}{8}$ Day $3$ | $1\dfrac{3}{8}$  **Create a line plot that shows all of the measurements on the number line below.**    *Click above tick marks to add dots; click on tick marks to remove dots.*

hints.content: The number line has $8$ equal parts per whole, so each interval has a length of $\dfrac{1}{8}$.   Let's number the rest of the number line.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line that has, moving left to right, labeled tick marks at one, one and one-eighth, one and one-fourth, one and three-eighths, one and one-half, one and five-eighths, one and three-fourths, one and seven-eighths, and two. The tick marks at 1 and 2 are emphasized.

hints.content: There are repeats in the data. Let's summarize the information into a frequency table.  Rainfall (in) | Frequency :-: | :-: $1\dfrac{1}{8}$ | $1$ $1\dfrac{3}{8}$ | $2$  The frequency tells us how many dots to put above each number on the line plot.  For example, we need $2$ dots above the value $1\dfrac{3}{8}$ inches.  Now we can plot each measurement and its frequency.
The correctly graphed measurements are:    [[☃ plotter 1]]

question.content: A family picked apples at an orchard. The table below shows how much each person picked, to the nearest $\dfrac{1}{4}$ bushel.  Person | Volume (bushels) :-: | :-: Saul | $1\dfrac{1}{4}$ Adrian | $1\dfrac{3}{4}$ Boden | $\dfrac{3}{4}$ Lize | $\dfrac{3}{4}$ Nyla | $1\dfrac{3}{4}$  **Create a line plot that shows all of the measurements on the number line below.**    *Click above tick marks to add dots; click on tick marks to remove dots.*

hints.content: The number line has $4$ equal parts per whole, so each interval has a length of $\dfrac{1}{4}$.   Let's number the rest of the number line.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line that has, moving left to right, labeled tick marks at one, one and one-fourth, one and one-half, one and three-fourths, two, two and one-fourth, two and one-half, two and three-fourths, three, three and one-fourth, three and one-half, three and three-fourths, and four. The tick marks at 1, 2, 3, and 4 are emphasized.

hints.content: There are repeats in the data. Let's summarize the information into a frequency table.  Volume (bushels) | Frequency :-: | :-: $1\dfrac{1}{4}$ | $1$ $1\dfrac{3}{4}$ | $2$ $\dfrac{3}{4}$ | $2$  The frequency tells us how many dots to put above each number on the line plot.  For example, we need $2$ dots above the value $1\dfrac{3}{4}$ bushels.  Now we can plot each measurement and its frequency.
The correctly graphed measurements are:    [[☃ plotter 1]]

question.content: A produce stand is selling baskets of peaches. The table below shows the different weights of each basket.  Measurements are rounded to the nearest $\dfrac{1}{8}$ of a pound.  Weight (pounds) | Number of baskets :-: | :-: $5$ | $1$ $4\dfrac{1}{8}$ | $3$ $4\dfrac{3}{4}$ | $4$ $4\dfrac{1}{2}$ | $4$ $4\dfrac{3}{8}$ | $2$  **Create a line plot that shows all of the measurements on the number line below.**    *Click above tick marks to add dots; click on tick marks to remove dots.*

hints.content: The number line has $8$ equal parts per whole, so each interval has a length of $\dfrac{1}{8}$.   Let's number the rest of the number line.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line that has, moving left to right, labeled tick marks at four, four and one-eighth, four and one-fourth, four and three-eighths, four and one-half, four and five-eighths, four and three-fourths, four and seven-eighths, and five. The tick marks at 4 and 5 are emphasized.

hints.content: The number of baskets tells us how many dots to put above each number on the line plot.  For example, we need $2$ dots above the value $4\dfrac{3}{8}$ pounds.  Now we can plot each measurement and its frequency.
The correctly graphed measurements are:    [[☃ plotter 1]]

question.content: Amy ran many miles during September. She recorded how long it took her to run each mile, rounded to the nearest $\dfrac{1}{4}$ of a minute, on the table below.  Time (min) | Frequency :-: | :-: $8\dfrac{3}{4}$ | $3$ $9\dfrac{1}{4}$ | $2$ $9\dfrac{1}{2}$ | $4$ $8\dfrac{1}{2}$ | $1$ $9$ | $5$   **Create a line plot that shows all of the measurements on the number line below.**    *Click above tick marks to add dots; click on tick marks to remove dots.*

hints.content: The number line has $4$ equal parts per whole, so each interval has a length of $\dfrac{1}{4}$.   Let's number the rest of the number line.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line that has, moving left to right, labeled tick marks at eight, eight and one-fourth, eight and one-half, eighth and three-fourths, nine, nine and one-fourth, nine and one-half, nine and three-fourths, and ten. The tick marks at 8, 9, and 10 are emphasized.

hints.content: The frequency tells us how many dots to put above each number on the line plot.  For example, we need $3$ dots above the value $8\dfrac{3}{4}$ minutes.  Now we can plot each measurement and its frequency.
The correctly graphed measurements are:    [[☃ plotter 1]]

question.content: The table below  gives the heights of the saplings that Ms. Valendra’s science class planted.  The measurements are rounded to the nearest $\dfrac{1}{4}$ of an inch.  Height (in) | Number of saplings :-: | :-: $8\dfrac{1}{4}$ | $2$ $8\dfrac{3}{4}$ | $3$ $8\dfrac{1}{2}$ | $5$ $7\dfrac{1}{2}$ | $4$ $9$ | $1$ $7\dfrac{3}{4}$ | $2$  **Create a line plot that shows all of the measurements on the number line below.**    *Click above tick marks to add dots; click on tick marks to remove dots.*

hints.content: The number line has $4$ equal parts per whole, so each interval has a length of $\dfrac{1}{4}$.   Let's number the rest of the number line.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line that has, moving left to right, labeled tick marks at seven and one-half, seven and three-fourths, eight, eight and one-fourth, eight and one-half, eight and three-fourths, and nine. The tick marks at 8 and 9 are emphasized.

hints.content: The number of saplings tells us how many dots to put above each number on the line plot.  For example, we need $2$ dots above the value $8\dfrac{1}{4}\,\text{inch}$.  Now we can plot each measurement and its frequency.
The correctly graphed measurements are:    [[☃ plotter 1]]

question.content: The table below shows the volumes of baking soda from several trials of a science experiment. The measurements are rounded to the nearest $\dfrac{1}{8}$ teaspoon.  Volume (teaspoons) | Number of trials :-: | :-: $2\dfrac{1}{2}$ | $3$ $3\dfrac{1}{2}$ | $4$ $3\dfrac{1}{8}$ | $2$ $2\dfrac{5}{8}$ | $2$ $3\dfrac{1}{4}$ | $4$ $3\frac{3}{4}$ | $1$  **Create a line plot that shows all of the measurements on the number line below.**    *Click above tick marks to add dots; click on tick marks to remove dots.*

hints.content: The number line has $8$ equal parts per whole, so each interval has a length of $\dfrac{1}{8}$.   Let's number the rest of the number line.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line that has, moving left to right, labeled tick marks at two, two and one-eighth, two and one-fourth, two and three-eighths, two and one-half, two and five-eighths, two and three-fourths, two and seven-eighths, three, three and one-eighth, three  and one-fourth, three and three-eighths, three and one-half, three and five-eighths, three and three-fourths, three and seven-eighths, and four. The tick marks at 2, 3 and 4 are emphasized.

hints.content: The number of trials tells us how many dots to put above each number on the line plot.  For example, we need $3$ dots above the value $2\dfrac{1}{2}$ teaspoons.  Now we can plot each measurement and its frequency.
The correctly graphed measurements are:    [[☃ plotter 1]]

question.content: The table below shows the volumes of shampoo Nyla used for several days. The measurements are rounded to the nearest $\dfrac{1}{8}$ ounce.  Volume (ounces) | Number of days :-: | :-: $\dfrac{1}{2}$ | $5$ $\dfrac{3}{8}$ | $4$ $\dfrac{1}{4}$ | $2$ $\dfrac{5}{8}$ | $4$ $\dfrac{3}{4}$ | $1$  **Create a line plot that shows all of the measurements on the number line below.**    *Click above tick marks to add dots; click on tick marks to remove dots.*

hints.content: The number line has $8$ equal parts per whole, so each interval has a length of $\dfrac{1}{8}$.   Let's number the rest of the number line.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line that has, moving left to right, labeled tick marks at zero, one-eighth, one-fourth, three-eighths, one-half, five-eighths, three-fourths, seven-eighths, and one. The tick marks at 0 and 1 are emphasized.

hints.content: The number of days tells us how many dots to put above each number on the line plot.  For example, we need $5$ dots above the value $\dfrac{1}{2}$ of an ounce.  Now we can plot each measurement and its frequency.
The correctly graphed measurements are:    [[☃ plotter 2]]

question.content: The table below shows the distances students walked or ran during their gym class. The measurements are rounded to the nearest $\dfrac{1}{4}$ mile.  Distance (miles) | Number of students :-: | :-: $\dfrac{1}{2}$ | $6$ $\dfrac{3}{4}$ | $3$ $1\dfrac{1}{4}$ | $5$ $1$ | $5$ $2\dfrac{1}{4}$ | $1$  **Create a line plot that shows all of the measurements on the number line below.**    *Click above tick marks to add dots; click on tick marks to remove dots.*

hints.content: The number line has $4$ equal parts per whole, so each interval has a length of $\dfrac{1}{4}$.   Let's number the rest of the number line.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line that has, moving left to right labeled tick marks at zero, one-fourth, one-half, three-fourths, one, one and one-fourth, one and one-half, one and three-fourths, two, two and one-fourth, and two and one-half. The tick marks at 0, 1, and 2 are emphasized.

hints.content: The number of students tells us how many dots to put above each number on the line plot.  For example, we need $6$ dots above the value $\dfrac{1}{2}$ of a mile.  Now we can plot each measurement and its frequency.
The correctly graphed measurements are:    [[☃ plotter 3]]
